hints_html:
Make a sketch of the region of integration and consider a change of variables.

Change the cartesian variables \(\displaystyle (x,y)\) to polar coordinates \(\displaystyle (r,\phi)\), where the boundaries of the radius are \(\displaystyle r \in [0, \sqrt{2}]\) and of the angle are \(\displaystyle \phi\in\left[0,\frac{\pi}{4}\right]\).
hints_latex:
Make a sketch of the region of integration and consider a change of
variables.

Change the cartesian variables $\displaystyle (x,y)$ to polar
coordinates $\displaystyle (r,\phi)$, where the boundaries of the radius
are $\displaystyle r \in [0, \sqrt{2}]$ and of the angle are
$\displaystyle \phi\in\left[0,\frac{\pi}{4}\right]$.
hints_raw:
Make a sketch of the region of integration and consider a change of variables.
Change the cartesian variables <math>\displaystyle (x,y) </math> to polar coordinates <math>\displaystyle (r,\phi)</math>, where the boundaries of the radius are <math>\displaystyle r \in [0, \sqrt{2}] </math> and of the angle are <math>\displaystyle \phi\in\left[0,\frac{\pi}{4}\right] </math>.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
We use the change of variables from cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \begin{pmatrix}x\\y\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}r\cos(\phi)\\r\sin(\phi)\end{pmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

The region of integration in polar coordinates is \(\displaystyle D=\{(r,\phi)|\ r\in[0,\sqrt{2}],\ \phi\in[0,\frac{\pi}{4}]\}\). The function \(\displaystyle y\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\) becomes \(\displaystyle r^2\sin(\phi)\). The volume factor for polar coordinates is \(\displaystyle r\). Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} \iint_Dy\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\;\text{d}A &= \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{4}}r^2\sin(\phi)r\;\text{d}\phi\text{d}r\\ &= \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}r^3[-\cos(\phi)]_0^{\frac\pi4}\;\text{d}r\\ &= \left[\frac14r^4\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}}(-\cos(\frac\pi4) + \cos(0))\\ &= 1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We use the change of variables from cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates: <math>\displaystyle \begin{pmatrix}x\\y\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}r\cos(\phi)\\r\sin(\phi)\end{pmatrix}</math>

The region of integration in polar coordinates is <math>\displaystyle D=\{(r,\phi)|\ r\in[0,\sqrt{2}],\ \phi\in[0,\frac{\pi}{4}]\} </math>. The function <math>\displaystyle y\sqrt{x^2+y^2} </math> becomes <math>\displaystyle r^2\sin(\phi)</math>. The volume factor for polar coordinates is <math>\displaystyle r</math>. Hence,

:<math>\displaystyle \begin{align}
\iint_Dy\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\;\text{d}A &= \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{4}}r^2\sin(\phi)r\;\text{d}\phi\text{d}r\\
=& \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}r^3[-\cos(\phi)]_0^{\frac\pi4}\;\text{d}r\\
=& \left[\frac14r^4\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}}(-\cos(\frac\pi4) + \cos(0))\\
=& 1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{align}</math>
statement_html: Evaluate the double integral \(\displaystyle \iint_{D}y\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}\,dA\) over the region \(\displaystyle D = \{(x,y)\,|\,x^{2} + y^{2} \le 2 \,\,\mbox{and}\,\, 0 \le y \le x\}\).
statement_latex:
Evaluate the double integral
$\displaystyle \iint_{D}y\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}\,dA$ over the region
$\displaystyle D = \{(x,y)\,|\,x^{2} + y^{2} \le 2 \,\,\mbox{and}\,\, 0 \le y \le x\}$.
statement_raw: Evaluate the double integral <math>\displaystyle \iint_{D}y\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}\,dA</math> over the region <math>\displaystyle D = \{(x,y)\,|\,x^{2} + y^{2} \le 2 \,\,\mbox{and}\,\, 0 \le y \le x\}</math>.
